Facility Name: Speer Plant

Platteville, CO 80651



Parent Company: Aka Energy Group, LLC



RMP Facility ID: 100000229987



AKA ENERGY GROUP, LLC

SPEER PLANT



RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN



Executive Summary



Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:



The Speer Plant Emergency Action Plan is site-specific. It includes required actions by plant employees as well as required notification and coordination with local responders and agencies. All employees are trained in the execution of the Emergency Action Plan.



The Stationary Source and Regulated substances:



The Speer Plant is a natural gas liquid stabilization plant. Raw natural gas enters the plant by pipeline. Natural gas liquids are separated from the gas stream in the facility's inlet slug catcher. The finished product from the stabilization plant is stored onsite and loaded into trucks for local sale.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program:



The Speer Plant has implemented all the elements of a Program 1 Risk Management Plan (RMP) and many of the elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program. Key elements of these programs include:



Employee Participation: Employees are consulted on the development of the required elements of the RMP Program. Employees participate by developing, revising, and auditing the RMP program where applicable.



Process Safety Information: A variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): A systematic examination of the plant to identify possible hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.



Operating Procedures: The Speer Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) initial start-up, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) emergency operations, (6) normal shutdown, and (7) startup after turnaround.



Training: The plant has imp

lemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. The program includes Classroom, OJT, and written testing. Employees are tested to demonstrate competency.



Contractors: Speer Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors, (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) are aware of any hazards in the workplace, (3) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (4) understand and follow site safety rules, and (5) inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.



Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR): The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing modified equipment into service.



Mechanical Integrity: The Speer Plant has well established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in safe operating condition.



Management of Change: Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.



Incident Investigation: The goal of each investigation is to determine the causes of an incident or near miss and to develop actions to prevent recurrence of a similar incident.



Compliance Audits: Audits are conducted on a regular basis to ensure that the facility is in compliance with applicable RMP procedures and regulations.



Safe Work Practices and Procedures: Examples of safe work practices include methods for controlling plant entry, presence and exit of support personnel, lockout/ tagout procedures to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenanc

e, hot work procedures and permits for work with the potential for generating ignition sources in the presence of flammable or combustible material, and confined space entry permits and procedures to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry is allowed into a permit required confined space.



In addition, the plant utilizes a computerized process control system that will safely shut down the operation if the process exceeds safe operating conditions. The computerized process control system has its own power backup.



Five-year Accident History:



No major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion, involving one or more regulated substances that presents imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment. has occurred in the last 5 years.



Emergency Response Program Information:



The Speer Plant maintains a written emergency response program to protect employees, contractors, public and the environment from hazards associated with accidental releases of regulated substances. The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of regulated substances, including the possibility of associated fires or explosions. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, if a release occurs. Employees receive training in these procedures annually to perform emergency response duties. The program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the gas plant processes. Emergency response program changes are administered through the Management of Change process.



The overall emergency response program for the Speer Plant is coordinated with the La Salle Fire Protection District. This coordination includes attending periodic meetings, which includes local emergency response officials and industry representatives. The Speer Plant has 24-hour communications capability

with the La Salle Fire Protection District.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



Aka is a member of various industry trade organizations that continuously review changes in technology that lead to improved safety practices.
